factoid: Prince Andrew heard a whisper of a woman's voice while it was being given.
Prince Andrew heard the rustle of a silk dress behind a door.
Prince Andrew noticed behind the door a plump, rosy, handsome woman in a pink dress with a lilac silk kerchief on her head, holding a dish and awaiting the entrance of the commander in chief.
Kutúzov's adjutant whispered to Prince Andrew that the woman behind the door was the wife of the priest whose home it was.
The priest's wife intended to offer Prince Andrew bread and salt.
The priest's husband welcomed Prince Andrew with a cross at the church.
The priest's wife intends to welcome Prince Andrew in the house.
The priest's wife is very pretty.
Kutúzov looked around when he heard the adjutant's words.
Kutúzov was listening to the general's report.
The general's report consisted chiefly of a criticism of the position at Tsárevo-Zaymíshche.
Kutúzov had listened to Denísov.
Kutúzov had listened to the discussion at the Austerlitz council of war seven years previously.
Kutúzov had ears with a piece of tow in one of them, but could still hear.
Nothing the general said would surprise or interest Kutúzov.
Kutúzov knew all that would be said beforehand.
Kutúzov heard the general's report because he had to, as one has to listen to the chanting of a service of prayer.
Denísov had said clever and to the point.
The general was saying even more clever and to the point.
Kutúzov despised knowledge and cleverness.
Kutúzov despised something else that would decide the matter—something independent of cleverness and knowledge.
Prince Andrew watched the commander in chief's face attentively.
The only expression Prince Andrew could see on the commander in chief's face was boredom.
The only expression Prince Andrew could see on the commander in chief's face was curiosity about the feminine whispering behind the door.
The only expression Prince Andrew could see on the commander in chief's face was a desire to observe propriety.
It was evident that Kutúzov despised cleverness and learning and even the patriotic feeling shown by Denísov.
Kutúzov despised them not because of his own intellect, feelings, or knowledge.
Kutúzov despised them because of his old age and experience of life.
The only instruction Kutúzov gave during the report referred to looting by the Russian troops.

At the end of the report the general put before Kutúzov a paper relating to the recovery of payment from army commanders for green oats mown down by the soldiers, when landowners lodged petitions for compensation.
After hearing the matter Kutúzov smacked his lips together and shook his head.

Kutúzov said: "Into the stove... into the fire with it! I tell you once for all, my dear fellow, into the fire with all such things! Let them cut the crops and burn wood to their hearts' content. I don't order it or allow it, but I don't exact compensation either. One can’t get on without it. 'When wood is chopped the chips will fly.'"
Kutúzov looked at the paper again.
Kutúzov muttered, shaking his head: "Oh, this German precision!"
Kutúzov signed the last of the documents, rose heavily, smoothed out the folds in his fat white neck, and moved toward the door with a more cheerful expression.

The priest's wife, flushing rosy red, caught up the dish she had after all not managed to present at the right moment, though she had been preparing for it for so long, and with a low bow offered it to Kutúzov.
Kutúzov screwed up his eyes, smiled, lifted the priest's wife's chin with his hand, and said: "Ah, what a beauty! Thank you, sweetheart!"
Kutúzov took some gold pieces from his trouser pocket and put them on the dish for the priest's wife.
Kutúzov said: "Well, my dear, and how are we getting on?" to the priest's wife.
Kutúzov moved to the door of the room assigned to him.
The priest's wife smiled, and with dimples in her rosy cheeks followed Kutúzov into the room.
The adjutant came out to the porch and asked Prince Andrew to lunch with him.
Half an hour later Prince Andrew was again called to Kutúzov.
Prince Andrew found Kutúzov reclining in an armchair, still in the same unbuttoned overcoat.
Kutúzov had a French book in his hand which he closed as Prince Andrew entered.
The book was Les Chevaliers du Cygne by Madame de Genlis.
